criteres_selection
Lorsque vous étiez en train de chercher une structure pour effectuer votre Service Civique, quels ont été vos critères de sélection ?
La durée hebdomadaire; L'activité proposée ou le public côtoyé; La thématique de la mission (social, culture, éducation, etc.); Le type de structure (association, collectivité territoriale, etc.); La possibilité de faire votre Service Civique en équipe; La situation géographique de la structure; Le lien avec vos études et/ou votre projet professionnel; La possibilité d'alterner l'école et le Service Civique; La possibilité de réaliser votre projet; L'avis d'un.e ancien.ne volontaire


attrait_structure_accueil
Au moment où vous avez déposé votre candidature, qu’est-ce qui vous a le plus attiré(e) chez Unis-Cité (ou votre structure d'accueil) ?
La possibilité de réaliser différents projets; Le travail en équipe; La préparation de mon projet d'avenir; La rencontre avec différents publics; La réflexion sur des enjeux de société; L'état d'esprit de la structure (valeurs, ambiance, etc.); La rencontre avec des jeunes d'horizons divers; Le fait d'agir concrètement pour les autres; L'alternance entre l'école et le Service Civique; La préparation de mon projet d'avenir; La rencontre avec différents publics; La réflexion sur des enjeux de société; L'état d'esprit de la structure (valeurs, ambiance, etc.); La rencontre avec des jeunes d'horizons divers; Le fait d'agir concrètement pour les autres; L'alternance entre l'école et le Service Civique


apport_service_civique
A votre avis, que pourrait principalement vous apporter votre Service Civique ?
Des compétences nouvelles; Une maturité personnelle; Une ouverture aux autres; Une orientation professionnelle; La possibilité de poursuivre ma scolarité; Un accompagnement pour réaliser mon projet; Un changement de vie; Une connaissance de la société; Une expérience de terrain; Un réseau professionnel


preparation_recherche_emploi
Si vous deviez chercher un emploi, vous sentez-vous correctement préparé(e) à le faire (faire une lettre de motivation, passer un entretien de recrutement…) ?
Oui; Pas vraiment; Non


idee_metier_souhaite
Avez-vous déjà une idée du métier que vous souhaiteriez exercer ?
Oui; Pas vraiment; Non


secteurs_travail_souhaite
Dans quel(s) secteur(s) souhaiteriez-vous travailler ?
Agriculture, pêche; Artisanat; Arts, culture et spectacle; Banque, assurance, immobilier; Bâtiment et travaux publics; Electronique, mécanique; Commerce, distribution, vente; Santé, Social; Services aux personnes; Droit; Communication, médias, marketing, RH; Accueil, secrétariat, gestion administrative; Enseignement, formation, recherche; Informatique, télécommunications; Energie, environnement, chimie; Logistique, transport; Audit, comptabilité, finance; Tourisme, hôtellerie, restauration


ressources_avant_sc
Quelles étaient en moyenne vos ressources par mois avant le Service Civique ? [tenez compte de l’ensemble de vos revenus, y compris non déclarés]
Moins de 100€; Entre 100 et 500€; Entre 500 et 1000€; Entre 1000 et 1500€; Plus de 1500€


benevolat_avant_sc
Avant votre Service Civique, avez-vous été bénévole ?
Oui; Non


perception_vote
D'une manière générale, pour vous, voter c'est plutôt :
Un devoir citoyen; Un droit; Une responsabilité; Une corvée; Une manière d'agir sur le monde; Une action inutile


vote_derniers_elections
Avez-vous voté lors des dernières élections (locales ou nationales) ?
Oui; Non; Vous n'aviez pas l'âge de voter ou vous n'étiez pas inscrit.e sur les listes électorales


projet_fin_sc
Savez-vous ce que vous ferez à la fin de votre Service Civique ?
Non, aucune idée; Non, mais le Service Civique va m'aider à y réfléchir; Oui, je vais reprendre mes études, préparer un concours; Oui, je vais chercher une formation professionnelle; Oui, je vais chercher un emploi; Oui, je vais créer mon activité; Oui, je vais poursuivre mon projet solidaire; Oui, je vais faire un autre volontariat


perception_avenir
Concernant votre avenir, êtes-vous...?
Très confiant(e); Assez confiant(e); Peu confiant(e); Pas du tout confiant(e)


action_individuelle_societe
En général, pensez-vous que votre action individuelle peut contribuer à changer la société ?
Oui; Pas vraiment; Non


satisfaction
D'une manière générale, diriez-vous que votre Service Civique s'est déroulé de façon...
Très satisfaisante; Assez satisfaisante; Peu satisfaisante; Pas du tout satisfaisante


differences_equipe
Avez-vous eu le sentiment que les membres de votre équipe étaient...

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
text:
In this report, we address three main questions regarding volunteers who do there service civique in France:

Who are the volunteers? (Section 2)
How does the service civique change the volunteers’ attitudes and views? (Section 3)
Are there trends between different cohorts of volunteers? (Section 4)
What predicts whether volunteers…


…end their contract early? (Section 5.1)
…are more satisfied ? (Section 5.2)
…are more confident about their future? (Section 5.3)


How do volunteers differ between the different programs?


Ciné (Section 6.1)
Ecology (Section 6.2)

We rely on questionnaires collected by Cité-Unis for four different cohorts of volunteers who did their service civique for a year (2020-2021; 2021-2022; 2022-2023; 2023-2024). These questionnaires are very extensive. For the present analyses, we selected a subset of key questions (a full list can be found in the codebook). Note that this selection of variables was based only on the questionnaire of the first cohort (2020/21). As a result, potentially interesting variables that only appear in later questionnaires will not appear here.

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
text:
Geographic location
Volunteers came from 80 different departments (see Figure 1). On average, across the different cohorts, most volunteers came from Bouches-du-Rhône (n = 404), followed by Nord (n = 350) and Seine-Saint-Denis (n = 316).
Overall, there has been a steady increase in volunteers, from 6386 in 20-21 to 7848 in 23-24, and an average increase of 490.4 per year. Since the 20-21 cohort, each departement has on average increased by 26.7. There were 51 departements who saw an increase, and 14 who saw a decrease (see Figure 2). For details on the trend of each departement, see Tables.








Figure 1: Répartition des volontaires en France à travers le temps.













Figure 2: Evolution de recrutement pour la promo de 2023-24 par rapport à 2020-21.

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
text:
Age
Across all promos, the majority of volunteers is between 18 and 20 years old (Figure 3).











(a) (absolute numbers)











(b) (percentages)







Figure 3: Number of volunteers per age group, within the different promos. Note that in the percentage plot, the percentages are relative to all volunteers from the respective promo.

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
text:
Education
As shown in Figure 4, volunteers with a “Bac + 3 et plus” are relatively rare. The share of volunteers with a “Bac à Bac + 2” has been constantly decreasing, from 48% in 2020/21 to 40% in 2023/24. By contrast, volunteers “Infra-bac”, have been increasing from 32% in 2020/21 to 43% in 2023/24.











(a) (absolute numbers)











(b) (percentages)







Figure 4: Number of volunteers per education level, within the different promos. Note that in the percentage plot, the percentages are relative to all volunteers from the respective promo.

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
text:
Sex
There is a relatively stable difference regarding sex, with more women (~60%) being volunteers than men (Figure 5).











(a) (absolute numbers)











(b) (percentages)







Figure 5: Number of male and female volunteers, within the different promos. Note that in the percentage plot, the percentages are relative to all volunteers from the respective promo.

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
text:
Voting
The figures in this section shows all volunteers who answered the question [XX] at both time points (q1 and q2), with either “yes” or “no”, for the different promos (promo 2020-21, Figure 7; promo 2021-22, Figure 8; 2022-23, Figure 9; 2023-24, Figure 10).
This descriptive analysis suggests that the service civique did not have an impact on voting behavior, on average. However, this analysis is pooled across different cohorts, not all of which would have had the chance to change their voting behavior during their year volunteering, simply because there were no elections.

Promo 2020-21











(a) Alluvial plot











(b) Percentages







Figure 7: Promo 2020-21. Change in volunteers reporting whether they voted or not during the last elections, between Q1 and Q2. Note that this analysis considers only answers of volunteers who answered either yes or no at both time points.





Promo 2021-22











(a) Alluvial plot











(b) Percentages







Figure 8: Promo 2021-22. Change in volunteers reporting whether they voted or not during the last elections, between Q1 and Q2. Note that this analysis considers only answers of volunteers who answered either yes or no at both time points.





Promo 2022-23











(a) Alluvial plot











(b) Percentages







Figure 9: Promo 2022-23. Change in volunteers reporting whether they voted or not during the last elections, between Q1 and Q2. Note that this analysis considers only answers of volunteers who answered either yes or no at both time points.





Promo 2023-24











(a) Alluvial plot











(b) Percentages







Figure 10: Promo 2023-24. Change in volunteers reporting whether they voted or not during the last elections, between Q1 and Q2. Note that this analysis considers only answers of volunteers who answered either yes or no at both time points.

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
text:
Acting for society
The figures in this section show changes in volunteers perception on whether their individual action can contribute to changing society, for the different promos (promo 2020-21, Figure 11; promo 2021-22, Figure 8; 2022-23, Figure 9; 2023-24, Figure 10)1. Descriptively, there is no clear positive or negative trend either.

Promo 2020-21











(a) Alluvial plot











(b) Percentages







Figure 11: Promo 2020-21. Change in volunteers reporting whether they think their individual action can contribute to changing society, between Q1 and Q2. Note that this analysis considers only answers of volunteers who answered at both time points.





Promo 2021-22











(a) Alluvial plot











(b) Percentages







Figure 12: Promo 2021-22. Change in volunteers reporting whether they think their individual action can contribute to changing society, between Q1 and Q2. Note that this analysis considers only answers of volunteers who answered at both time points.





Promo 2022-23











(a) Alluvial plot











(b) Percentages







Figure 13: Promo 2022-23. Change in volunteers reporting whether they think their individual action can contribute to changing society, between Q1 and Q2. Note that this analysis considers only answers of volunteers who answered at both time points.

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
text:
Satisfaction
Figure 14 shows how different cohorts evaluated their satisfaction with the service civique.








Figure 14: Satisfaction between cohorts.

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
section: What predicts whether volunteers end their contract early (rupture)?
text:
What predicts whether volunteers end their contract early (rupture)?
Figure 15 shows how many volunteers have ended their contract early (rupture), for the different promos. Figure 16 provides an overview of the different reasons, pooling all promos.











(a) (absolute numbers)











(b) (percentages)







Figure 15: Number of volunteers with a rupture (for various possible reasons, including positive ones, such as obtaining a work contract).











Figure 16: Prevalence of different rupture motives





Not all volunteers work until the end of their contract. In fact, 22.9% of volunteers have a “rupture”, i.e. terminate the contract early. There are various motives for ending one’s contract early (see Table 1). Not all of them are necessarily bad, e.g. “Embauche en CDD d’au moins 6 mois ou CDI”, and some are outside of the influence of the volunteers, e.g. “Fin de validité du Titre de Séjour”. For our analyses, we focus only on volunteers who ended their contract early for apparently negative reasons.
To see whether there are differences in different groups, we ran separate logistic regressions for a selection of variables. The results are shown in Figure 17. Because the magnitude of the odds ratios (OR) are not straightforward to interpret, Figure 18 shows descriptive differences in contract terminations for some groups.




Table 1: Different motives for “rupture” and whether they were coded as negative, positive, or external reasons.






motif_rupture
rupture_valence
n




01 - Abandon de poste
negative
1444


02 - Faute grave d'une des parties
negative
455


03 - Force majeure
negative

04 - Embauche en CDD d'au moins 6 mois ou CDI
positive
621


05 - Embauche en CDD moins de 6 mois
positive

06 - Commun accord entre les parties

07 - Le volontaire n'a jamais pris son poste

08 - Retrait de l'agrément de la structure d'accueil

09 - Reprise d'études

10 - Fin de validité du Titre de Séjour
raisons externes

NA
21549
















Figure 17: Effects of demographic factors on negative rupture. Coefficients are the results of separate logistic regressions for each variable. For categorical variables, a baseline has been chosen in the model (refer to the codebook to see the omitted baseline category). Each bar or dot in the chart shows how a factor (like age, gender, or education) relates to the chance of a rupture. An odds ratio of 1 means that this group has the same chance of a rupture as the baseline group. More than 1 means that this group is more likely to have a rupture. For example, an odds ratio of 2.0 means twice as likely. Less than 1 means that this group is less likely to have a rupture. An odds ratio of 0.5 means half as likely. The lines show uncertainty (confidence intervals). If they cross 1, the difference might not be meaningful (in this case, the result is not statistically significant). The logarithmic scale is used so that in the visualization for the positive and negative odds ratio’s to be symmetric (i.e. that 2 is as far away from 1 as is 0.5).













Figure 18: Percentages of rupture for (allegedly) negative reasons for different groups, for different variables.





How to make sense of the odds ratios? Take the example of the type of volunteers (type_volontaire). Table 2 shows the count, odds and share for rupture vs. no rupture for a negative motive.




Table 2: Count, odds and share for rupture vs. no rupture for a negative motive, according to which type of volunteer.

In this case the OR is odds of “CŒUR” divided by odds of “RELAIS” (OR = 1.6138667).
For non-demographic variables, investigating their relationship with rupture is not possible–simply because, by definition, for questions that have been only asked at “q2” and “q3”, volunteers who had ended their contract early were not available anymore (see Table 3). Only for the two variables that have been asked at “q1” (perception_avenir and action_individuelle_societe) we can look at their relationship with rupture (Figure 17).

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
section: What predicts whether volunteers are more satisfied ?
text:
What predicts whether volunteers are more satisfied ?
In this section, we look at satisfaction (“D’une manière générale, diriez-vous que votre Service Civique s’est déroulé de façon…” with levels 1, “pas du tout satisfaisainte”, to 4, “très satisfaisante”)2. As shown in Figure 19, taking all cohorts together, the majority of volunteers thinks their experience is “très satisfaisant”.








Figure 19: Répartition des niveaux de satisfaction





To see whether there are statistical differences between different categories of volunteers, we ran separate regression models for a selection of variables. The results are shown in Figure 20, for demographic variables, and Figure 21, for other variables. The estimates in these figures are the results of separate linear regressions for each variable. All likert scale type responses (such as satisfaction) have been coded as numeric (from 1 to 4). How to interpret the coefficients? For categorical variables, a baseline has been chosen in the model (refer to the codebook to see the omitted baseline category). The estimate shown in the graph is how much, compared to this baseline, satisfaction increases or decreases (on a scale from 1 to 4). For numeric variables, estimates represent how much satisfaction increases or decreases after increasing the variable by one unit.








Figure 20: Effects of demographic factors on satisfaction.













Figure 21: Effects of other, non-demographic factors on satisfaction.

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
section: What predicts whether volunteers are more confident in their future ?
text:
What predicts whether volunteers are more confident in their future ?
In this section, we look at confidence in one’s future (“Concernant votre avenir, êtes-vous…?” with levels 1, “Pas du tout confiant.e”, to 4, “Très confiant.e”)3. As shown in Figure 22, taking all cohorts together, the majority of volunteers are “assez confiant.e”.








Figure 22: Répartition des niveaux de satisfaction





To see whether there are statistical differences between different categories of volunteers, we ran separate regression models for a selection of variables. The results are shown in Figure 20, for demographic variables, and Figure 21, for other variables. The estimates in these figures are the results of separate linear regressions for each variable. All likert scale type responses (such as satisfaction) have been coded as numeric (from 1 to 4). How to interpret the coefficients? For categorical variables, a baseline has been chosen in the model (refer to the codebook to see the omitted baseline category). The estimate shown in the graph is how much, compared to this baseline, satisfaction increases or decreases (on a scale from 1 to 4). For numeric variables, estimates represent how much satisfaction increases or decreases after increasing the variable by one unit.








Figure 23: Effects of demographic factors on confidence in one’s future.













Figure 24: Effects of other, non-demographic factors on confidence in one’s future.

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
text:
Ciné
Volunteers who work in cine-related projects tend to be older and more educated. Refugies are less likely to be cine volunteers. If there is a preliminary end to the contract, cine volunteers are more likely to do so because they were offered a CDD of less than 6 months. Refugees are less likely to be cine volunteers, and women, as well as people from urban areas are more likely.








Figure 25: Differences in Ciné-related vs. other programs along demographic factors

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
text:
Ecovolonterre
Ecovolonterres tend to be older (mostly in the 21 to 23 agegroup) and more educated than other volunteers. They tend to plan for longer volunteer programs. Ecovolonterres tend to be from more rural but also urban ares (compared to QVP).








Figure 26: Differences in Ecovolonterre vs. other programs along demographic factors

title: Volunteer Report Cité-Unis
